{{Orphan|date=December 2010}} {| class="infobox" style="font-size:90%; text-align:left; width:23.5em" |- |colspan="3" bgcolor=#1874CD style="text-align: center; font-size: larger;" | ''' Cohuixca - Chontal Culture – Archaeological Site''' |- style="vertical-align: top; text-align: center;" |colspan=3 bgcolor="#FFFFFF" align="center"| |- | colspan="2" bgcolor=#1874CD | |- |colspan=2| |- | style="background:#efefef;"align="center" colspan="2" |[[File:Ixcateopansite5.JPG|thumb|300px|Part of the Ixcateopan archeological site]] |- | colspan="2" bgcolor=#1874CD | |- | '''Name:''' || Ixcateopan Archaeological Site |- | '''Type''' || Mesoamerican archaeology |- | '''Location''' || [[Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc]], [[Guerrero]]
{{MEX}} |- | '''Region''' || [[Mesoamerica]] |- |'''Coordinates''' || {{coord|18|29|50|N|99|47|36|W|type:city_region:MX|display=inline,title}} |- | '''Culture''' || Cohuixcas - Chontal – [[Mexica]] |- | '''Language''' || |- | '''Chronology''' || 350 to 1521 CE |- | '''Period''' || Mesoamerican Classical, Postclassical |- | '''Apogee''' || |- | '''[[INAH]] Web Page''' || [http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za01002.html# Ixcateopan zona arqueológica] {{es icon}} |} '''Ixcateopan''' is an archaeological site located in the town and municipality of [[Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc]], 36 kilometers from Taxco, in the isolated and rugged mountains of the northern part of [[Guerrero]] state, [[Mexico]]. The explored archeological remains are part of a city which functioned as an important regional ceremonial center. Ixcateopan was a place of cult and army garrisons inhabited by various native groups, such as the Cohuixcas (people of the place where there are lizards), The Chontales (foreigners)Chontal, from the Nahuatl word chontalli, means "foreigner", has been applied to various different ethnic groups in the Mesoamerican world and by the Aztecs, at the time when the latter were at war with the Purépecha.{{cite journal |last= Jiménez García |first= Elizabeth |date= |title= |trans-title=|journal= INAH, Based on the work of Robert Lister, Robert Barlow, Juan Yadeun, Eduardo Matos, Alejandro Pastrana, José Hernández, Mario Arturo Morales, Edgar Pavía y Raúl Vélez.|location= Mexico |url=http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za01002.html# |language=Spanish |format= |accessdate=Sep 2010}} The city is known as the final resting place of [[Cuauhtémoc]], the last [[Aztec]] [[Tlatoani]], whose remains were found under the parish church here in the mid-20th century. This church has been converted into a museum with displays a number of pre-Hispanic artifacts, offerings left in honor of the emperor and the remains of Cuauhtémoc himself.{{cite book |last=Quiroz Cuarón |first=Alfonso |title= Ichcateopan: La tumba de Cuauhtémoc – Héroe Supremo de la Historia de México|trans-title=Ixcateopan: The tomb of Cuahtemoc – Supreme Hero of the History of Mexico |year=2002 |publisher=Aconcagua Ediciones y Publicaciones, S. A. |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |pages=2–15 }} Only a portion of the "original" structures remain, as a result of a street construction and multiple sackings that have occurred by people seeking “carved” stones.{{cite web |first= |last= |title=Zonas Arqueológicas Guerrero|url= http://www.guerrero.gob.mx/?P=readart&ArtOrder=ReadArt&Article=66 |publisher=Government of Guerrero |location= |language= Spanish |trans-title=Guerrero Archaeological Sites |year= |accessdate= Sep 2010 }} Only the civic-religious section can be seen, constituted by several rooms and open spaces, where remains of red stucco in the floors can be observed, the main structure is of circular shape and might have been dedicated to Quetzalcoatl. The chronological placing of the site is from 1350 to 1521 CE. ==Background== The first humans in the state’s territory were nomadic hunter-gatherers who left evidence of their existence in various caves starting about 22,000 years ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_guerrero |title=Estado de Guerrero Historia |year=2005 |work=Enciclopedia de los Municipios de México |publisher=Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=State of Guerrero History |accessdate=June 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306003153/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_guerrero |archivedate=March 6, 2012 |df= }}{{cite web |url= http://www.guerrero.gob.mx/?P=readart&ArtOrder=ReadArt&Article=71 |title= La Riqueza Histórica de Guerrero |publisher= Government of Guerrero |location=Guerrero, Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Historical Richness of Guerrero |accessdate=June 24, 2010 }} Up until about 8,000 years ago, climatic conditions better favored human habitation than those today; however, sedimentary human habitation happened around this time in the mountainous areas with more moisture, and better soil for agriculture. After that, settlements appeared near the coast because of fishing.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-local.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/guerrero/medi.htm |title=Estado de Guerrero Medio Fisico |year=2005 |work=Enciclopedia de los Municipios de México |publisher=Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=State of Guerrero Environment |accessdate=June 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616191605/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/guerrero/medi.htm |archivedate=June 16, 2011 |df= }} At these sites, evidence of weaving, ceramics, basketry and other crafts have been found. Around this time, a grain called teocintle, or the forerunner to corn, became the staple of the diet. The first settlers of the state were the Olmecs during the Mesoamerican Preclassical period, establishing themselves in the vicinity of the Balsas River, living in caves. The chichimecas inhabited the Tierra Caliente region.{{cite journal |last= |first= |date= |title= Antecedentes históricos del Estado de Guerrero.|trans-title=Historical background of the State of Guerrero |journal= |location= |url= http://members.tripod.com/chilapa_gro.mx/ante_edogro.html|language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} There is debate as to whether the earliest civilizations here were [[Olmec]]s who migrated to this region or native peoples who were heavily influenced by the Olmecs, especially in the [[Balsas River|Mexcala River]] area. Olmec influences can be seen in cave paintings such as those found in [[Juxtlahuaca]] and well as stone tools and jade jewelry from the time period. Eventually, the peoples of the Mexcala River area developed their own [[Mezcala culture|distinctive culture]], called Mezcala or Mexcala. It is characterized by its own sculpture and ceramics, distinguished by its simplicity. Olmec influence remained with this culture, especially evident in the grouping of villages, construction of ceremonial centers and a government dominated by priests. Later, the culture assimilated aspects of the [[Teotihuacan]] model, which included the [[Mesoamerican ball game]] . Later migrations to the area brought ethnicities such as the [[Purépecha people|Purépecha]], the [[Mixtec]]s, the [[Maya peoples|Maya]] and the [[Zapotec peoples|Zapotec]]s who left traces on the local cultures as they established commercial centers around the 7th century. In the 8th century, [[Toltec]] influence was felt as they traveled the many trade routes through here in search of tropical bird plumage and [[amatl|amate paper]]. From the 12th century to the 15th, the various peoples of the state were influenced by the [[Chichimeca]]s, culminating in [[Aztec empire|Aztec domination]] by the 15th century. In the 11th century, new migrations entered the area from the north, which included the Nahuas, who occupied what is now the center of the state and the Purépecha who took over the west. The Nahuas established themselves in [[La Unión de Isidoro Montes de Oca|Zacatula]], [[Atoyac de Álvarez|Atoyac]] and [[Tlacotepec]], later conquering the areas occupied by the [[Putún Maya|Chontals]] and [[Matlatzinca people|Matlatzincas]]. By the 15th century, the territory of modern Guerrero state was inhabited by a number of peoples, none of whom had major cities or population centers. The most important of these peoples where the Purépecha, [[Cuitlatec people|Cuitlatec]]s, [[Ocuiteca]]s and Matlatzincas in the [[Tierra Caliente (Mexico)|Tierra Caliente]], the Chontales, [[Mazatleco]]s and [[Tlahuica]]s in the Sierra del Norte, the [[Coixca]]s and [[Tepozteco]]s in the Central Valleys, the Tlapanecos and Mixtecs in the La Montaña, the [[Jopi]]s, Mixtecos and [[Amuzgo people|Amuzgos]] in [[Costa Chica of Guerrero|Costa Chica]] and [[Tolimeca]]s, [[Chubia]]s, [[Panteca]]s and Cuitlecas in [[Costa Grande of Guerrero|Costa Grande]]. Most of these lived in smaller dominions with moderate social stratification. One distinctive feature of the peoples of this was the use of cotton garments. The Aztecs began making incursions in the Guerrero area as early as 1414 under [[Chimalpopoca]] as part of the conquest of the [[Toluca Valley]]. Incursions into the Tierra Caliente came around 1433 under [[Itzcoatl]] who attacked the Cuitlatecos settled between the [[Teloloapan River|Teloloapan]] and [[Cocula River]]s. By 1440, the Aztec Empire controlled the north of the state, or the mountainous areas. Attempts to take the Costa Chica area began in 1452 against the Yopis, which failed. Various battles would be fought between 1452 and 1511 before most of the rest of the state became Aztec tributary provinces. The modern state of Guerrero the comprised seven Aztec provinces. Some of the inhabitants of this area before the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Conquest]] were the Cohuixas and the [[Putún Maya|Chontals]]. The native community located at what is now the southern edge of the town dates back to at least 350 CE. This community was an important regional ceremonial center as well as the headquarters for the guardian soldiers. It was also closely associated with the production of cotton and cotton products, a valuable commodity at the time. Ixcateopan was one of the last cities to be subjugated by the [[Aztec Empire]]. The location served as a point to gather and then distribute tribute from surrounding areas. [[Mexica]] from other parts of the Aztec Empire, including soldiers, came here due to the wars between them and the [[Purépecha Empire]]. Because of this, Ixcateopan, originally a purely Chontal city, became multicultural.{{cite web |title= Ixcateopan may be Declared Archaeological Monuments Zone |url=http://dti.inah.gob.mx/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1668&Itemid=150 1 |publisher=INAH|date=September 2008 |accessdate=29 August 2009}} ===Tlatoani Cuauhtémoc=== Cuauhtémoc, the last Aztec [[Tlatoani]] (emperor), was born here in 1501. His mother, Cuayauhtitali, was the daughter of the Ixcateopan lord. Shortly before Cuauhtémoc was born, Ixcateopan was subjugated by the Aztecs and Cuayauhtitli was captured and brought to Tenochtitlan. There she met prince Ahuizotl, who married her. Cuauhtémoc was born of this union. Cuauhtémoc was educated in [[Tenochtitlan]] and then sent back to Ixcateopan. In 1519, he was ordered back to the Aztec capital to help defend it against the Spanish. After the deaths of Emperors [[Moctezuma II]] and, a short time later, [[Cuitláhuac]], Cuauhtémoc became emperor, but was a captive of [[Hernán Cortés]] when Tenochtitlan fell in 1521. After enduring much torture, he and nine other Aztec lords were hung near a place called Izancánac in what is now [[Chiapas]] state. The remains of Cuauhtémoc, the other Aztec lords and a priest who opposed their execution were brought to Ixcateopan and buried here.{{cite news |title= Sigue viva la memoria de Cuauhtémoc en Museo de Ixcateopan, Guerrero |trans-title=Cuahtémoc’s memory lives on at the Museum of Ixcateopan, Guerrero |url= http://www.turista.com.mx/article674.html |agency= Notimex |date=2009-08-25 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |language=Spanish }} From that time to the mid-20th century, the whereabouts of his tomb remained unknown. Fray Torbio de Benavente, the local evangelist, and Fray [[Bernardino de Sahagún]] wrote texts about the death and burial of Cuauhtémoc which were initially kept at the Church of San Hipólito in [[Mexico City]] but somehow wound up in the hands of the family of Salvador Rodriguez Juárez, who was the doctor of Ixcateopan in the first half of the 20th century. The documents had been passed down in his family for generations. They told of how Cuauhtémoc’s body had been recovered and brought to Ixcateopan and initially buried at the palace of his maternal grandparents in 1525. In 1529, Fray Toribio de Benavente had the body moved to a spot in front of the destroyed pagan temple, where the Church of Santa Maria de la Asunción would be built over it. The documents indicated that this tomb was nearly directly under the main altar of the church. After Rodríguez Juárez showed the documents to elders at the parish church, the Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (INAH) was contacted, which sent archeologist [[Eulalia Guzmán]] to investigate the authenticity of the documents. After examining the documents, investigating the oral traditions of the area and other archeological and historical evidence, it was decided to excavate in the place where the documents indicated. ===Toponymy=== The word Ixcateopan is of Nahuatl origin, from íxcatl or íchcatl, "Cotton", and teopan, teopancalli or teopantli, "temple", hence "cotton temple". Ixcateopan (sometimes spelled Ichcateopan) from the [[Nahuatl]] words “ichcacates” (or “ixcatle”) and “moteopan,” “teopan,” or “teopancalli.” Most interpret the first word as meaning cotton and the second temple, leading to a translation of temple of cotton. However, some sources claim the real name of the area is Zompancuahuithli, and the name was changed to Ixcateopan after the arrival of Cuauhtemoc's body and means (here is the temple/church). The glyph in the Mendoncino Codex for Ixcateopan reflects both interpretations, a cotton flower, a depiction of Cuauhtémoc and a pyramid.{{cite web |title= Ixcateopan |url= http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-guerrero-ixcateopan.php |language= Spanish |accessdate= 29 August 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100201211436/http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-guerrero-ixcateopan.php |archivedate= 1 February 2010 |df= }}{{cite web |title= Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc |url=http://www.guerrero.gob.mx/?P=ixcateopan_de_cuauhtemoc |publisher=State of Guerrero |language=Spanish |accessdate=29 August 2009}} “De Cuauhtémoc” was added to Ixcateopan’s name by the Congress of the State of Guerrero in 1950. However, according to the Mexico Municipalities Encyclopedia, Ixcateopan is a Nahuatl derived word, from the words Ichacates and Moteopan, which mean: "here is your Lord of great respect" according to this version, the ancient name of the municipality was Zompancuahuithli, other authors attribute the meaning to "here is the Church" and others "Temple of cotton".{{cite journal|last= |first= |date= |title=Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc |trans-title=|journal=Enciclopedia de los Municipios y Delegaciones de México |location=Mexico |url=http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_guerrero |language=Spanish |format= |accessdate=Sep 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306003153/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_guerrero |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }} Hieroglyphs in the [[Codex Mendoza]] represents two elements; a cotton flower called Ixcatl in Nahuatl placed on the steps of a pyramid representing a temple (in Nahuatl teopantli), the translated symbols of means: "in the Temple of cotton". As noted above, there were three main groups occupying the area, at one time or another, these were the Cohuixcas, Chontales and Aztecs. ===Cohuixcas=== Towards 1100 CE, the Nahua-Cohuixcas and [[Purépecha people|Purépecha]] arrived in the area; the Cohuixcas settled the central region of the State of Guerrero, founding the towns of: Taxco, Iguala, Tepecoacuilco, Huitzuco, Tlaxmalac, Cocula, Teloloapan, Atenango, Tlamacazapa, Ixcateopan, Acapetlahuaya, Zumpango del Rio, Tlapa, Tixtla, Acapulco and Chilapa. The Purépecha groups founded Pungarabato, Coyuca Zirándaro and took over throughout the Tierra Caliente region. They are referred to as Nahua-Cohuixcas, possibly because they spoke Nahuatl.The Nahuatl (derives from the words nāhua-tl, "clear or pleasant sound" and tlahtōl-li, "tongue or language) or Mexican is a Uto-Aztecan language spoken mainly by Mexico and Central America Nahuas. Emerged since at least the 7th century. Since the expansion of the Toltec at the end of 10th century Mesoamerican culture, Nahuatl began its diffusion over other mesoamerican languages to become the lingua franca in most of Mesoamerica, especially under territories conquered by the Mexicas, also called Aztecs, since the 13th century until their fall (August 13, 1521), this is the reason why the Nahuatl language is also known as the Mexican language. The Nahua name is given to different ethnic groups who have Nahuatl or Mexican as a common language. Nahuatl means "something that sounds good, such as bell" and also "cunning or crafty man" (Ladino).{{cite journal |last= |first= |date= |title= Los Nahuas del Estado de Guerrero |trans-title=The Nahua of the Guerrero State |journal=Buenas tareas |location= |url= http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/Los-Nahuas-Del-Estado-De-Guerrero/410259.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} The most important ethnic group in the Guerrero state was the Cohuixcas, who settled the central and northern regions. They came from northern territories. Coahuixca means "plain of snakes". The Cohuixcas were the oldest inhabitants of this region, within the Atenango del Rio municipality, upon the Spaniards arrival, they were tributaries of the Aztecs, who through their expeditions had come to dominate this region.{{cite journal |last= |first= |date= |title= La importancia de los sabios Cohuixcas |trans-title=The importance of the Cohuixca sages |journal=Buenas tareas |location= |url= http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/Grupos-En-La-Escuela/914221.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} The Chontales, Cohuixcas and other small fractions of peoples who spoke various languages, scattered from Guerrero to Oaxaca, nothing is known; modern people judges them from remains of tribes that preceded the Nations that left history traces. This opinion is not so risky; Humboldt in the past, had tried the same judgment, while incurring certain errors. «The Nations that successively invaded Mexico, he noted, the Toltec, the chichimecas, the nahuatlaques, the Acolhuas, the Tlaxcaltecas and the Aztecs, formed a single group, almost like the Germans, the Norwegians, Goths and Danes, mixed into a single race; the Germanic peoples.» It is likely, that other Nations such as the Otomi, Olmecs, Cuitlateques, Zacatecos and Purépecha, have appeared in the region before the Toltec. Wherever people have progressed in the same direction, the place they geographically occupy somehow designates the chronological order of their migrations. By the same rule can place the Nations who spoke lost languages. The last external offensive from forces loyal to the Aztecs came from the Malinalcas, Matlatzincas and Cohuixcas. Spaniards Andrés de Tapia and Gonzalo de Sandoval stop their advance.{{cite journal |last=Lopez Simon |first=Norma B. |date= |title= La conquista de Mexico|trans-title=The conquest of Mexico |journal=Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Facultad de estudios superiores, Aragón|location= Mexico|url=http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/La-Conquista-De-Mexico/230898.html|language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} ===Chontales=== There are two ethnic groups called Chontales, which do not have any cultural or linguistic relationship to each other:{{cite journal |last= |first= |date= |title= Chontales Oaxaca: Principales Grupos Indígenas |trans-title=Chontales Oaxaca: Major indigenous groups |journal= |location= |url= http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/Oaxaca/127703.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} ====Chontales of Tabasco==== '''Chontales de Tabasco''', as they are commonly known, another designation is mayas-chontales or Maya putunes in the academic environment.Roys (1996); Thompson (1975) As a result of the own struggles for social, political, economic demands, basic services, cultural rights and defense of their identity, the native groups call themselves, yoko-winik "the real man". The Chontal Supreme Council call themselves Yokokiniko ethnia: “real man and natives of these lands”.Hernandez (1988){{cite journal |last= Martínez Ruiz |first= José Luis |date= |title= Atlas de las Culturas del agua en América Latina y el caribe |trans-title=Atlas of wáter cultures in Latin America and the Caribbean |journal= Pueblos indígenas de Mexico y Agua: Yokotames de Tabasco |location= Instituto Mexicano de Tecnología del Agua |url= http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/04-Chontales-De-Tabasco/437315.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} This Chontal group is a descendant of the Mayans, the so-called Acalan-Tixchel chontales, and today are seated in the municipalities of Nacajuca, Centla, Jonuta, Macuspana and Center, in prehispanic times their presence extended to other municipalities such as Tenosique, Emiliano Zapata, Jalapa, Cardenas and Cunduacán.Roys: 1996 '''Yoko ochoco''', also known as '''Chontal Maya''', and '''Acalan''', is a [[Maya people|Maya]] [[Mayan languages|language]] of the [[Chol language|Cholan]] family spoken by the [[Chontal Maya people]] of the [[Mexican state]] of [[Tabasco]]. There are at least three [[dialects]], identified as Tamulté de las Sábanas Chontal, Buena Vista Chontal, and Miramar Chontal. ====Chontales of Oaxaca==== '''Chontales de Oaxaca''' or Tequistlatecos, the term comes from Tequisistlán, one of its main towns in the past. Their language, tequistlateco Joca-Meridional group and trunk Yumapacua, seems to be related with some languages of Baja California Norte, in the southeast of Mexico, Honduras and/or Nicaragua; however, to date their linguistic origin is still uncertain. There are dialect differences between speakers of the mountains and the coast, which hinders their mutual understanding. The '''Tequistlatecan languages''', also called '''Chontal of Oaxaca''', consists of three distinct languages. One called '''Huamelultec''' or '''Lowland Oaxaca Chontal''', '''Tequistlatec''' (which is probably extinct), and '''Highland Oaxaca Chontal'''. The ''Chontal'' languages are spoken by the Chontal people of the [[Mexican state]] of [[Oaxaca]]. Highland Chontal and Lowland Chontal (Huamelultec) are mutually unintelligible languages. The Tequistlatecan languages are part of some versions of the controversial [[Hokan languages|Hokan]] Macro-family proposal, but generally considered to be [[language isolate|isolates]]. Campbell and Oltrogge (1980) believe that the Tequistlatecan languages may be related to [[Jicaque people|Jicaquean]] but this hypothesis remains to be explored further. ==The Site== The archaeological site remains so far explored comprise a section that possibly functioned as an important ceremonial center at regional level. Ixcateopan was placed of cult and war goods storage inhabited by various native populations, such as Cohuixcas “people from the place with small lizards”, the chontales “foreigners” and by mexicas, at the time when they were at war with the purépecha. The buildings correspond to at least five different constructive periods; the complex was dedicated to religious ceremonies, administrative activities and trade.{{cite web|first=|last=|title=Turismo Arqueológico en Guerrero|url=http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-guerrero.php|publisher=Visiting Mexico|location=|language=Spanish|trans-title=Archaeological tourism in Guerrero|year=|accessdate=Sep 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811111741/http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-guerrero.php|archivedate=2010-08-11|df=}} After some Mexica military raids to areas near the [[Balsas River]], under the command of [[Itzcóatl]] fourth Mexica [[Tlatoani]] (from [[náhuatl]] tlahtoāni “the speaker”), the military success over the northern part of the current Guerrero State was formalized during the ruling of Moctezuma Ilhuicamina, fifth [[Mexica]] “huey tlatoani” from 1440 to 1469, during which period the people of Oztuma, Ixcateopan, Taxco, Tlaxmalac and Cuetzala were conquered. Therefore, Ixcateopan became a tributary province of Tepecoacuilco. The above was intimately associated with storage activities and clothing manufacturing from cotton, raw material that had to be the main source of supply and cult in the region. The archaeological zone is formed by a series of over laid structures built on the natural land elevation, it occupies approximately 5 thousand square meters. For construction they used local materials like: stone slabs, limestone and marble; for finishing, stucco and red paint was used. Finding of ancient instruments in the Ixcateopan archeological site corroborates that this place was subjugated by the Mexica military power.{{cite journal |last=Administrator |first= |date= May 3, 2010 |title= Hallazgo de antiguos instrumentos en la zona arqueológica de Ixcateopan corroboran que este lugar era sojuzgado por el poderío militar mexica |trans-title=Discovery of ancient instruments in the archaeological zone of Ixcateopan corroborate this place was dominated by Aztec military power |journal= Azteca |volume=21|location= |url= |language=Spanish |format= }} Ixcateopan was one of the last places conquered and dominated by the Mexica military power, becoming towards the end of the 15th and early 16th century, a tributary of the Triple Alliance; tools found at this archaeological site corroborate that this prehispanic site spun cotton for Tenochtitlan, which was used to make soldiers suits.{{cite web |first= |last= |title= Hallan en Ixcateopan un sitio que hilaba algodón a Tenochtitlán|url=http://www.periodicodigital.com.mx/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=110183&catid=37&Itemid=76|publisher=Periódico Digital|location= |language=Spanish|trans-title=Found in Ixcateopan a site that spun cotton for Tenochtitlan |date= May 4, 2010 |accessdate=Sep 2010}} In several site excavations ancient instruments were found, mainly spindle whorls apparatus (malacates[https://ucalgary.academia.edu/GeoffreyMcCafferty/Papers/137684/Textile_Production_in_Postclassic_Cholula_Mexico Mesoamerican Textile Production]), in the remains of some rooms. [[File:Malacate3.jpg|thumb|right|Ceramic Malacate]] [[File:Malacate.jpg|thumb|left|Ceramic Malacate]] ===Malacates=== The Malacates or disks with a central hole, sometimes referred to as “Rodelas” (washers), are complex to analyze. On the one hand, they have often been associated with spindle whorls, although there is little ethnographic documentation to support it was their main function.Moholy-Nagy: 2003 On the other hand, sometimes it is considered that these could have been beads or hanging decoration. It is difficult to consider other features for these curious samples.{{cite journal |last= Reyes, Mara A.|first= Laporte, Juan Pedro|date= |title= Cronología, contexto y función de los artefactos cerámicos en el sureste del Peten|trans-title=Chronology, context and function of ceramic artifacts in the southeast of the Petén |journal= |location= |url= http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/Hilar-Tapar-Jugar-cronologia-Contexto-Y-Funcion/1203179.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010}} The other functional possibility, that considered them as beads or hanging decoration, is somewhat complex to analyze, considering these are disks with perforated center holes and not precisely on its edges, as they could easily hung as necklace beads and pendant disks. In fact, the rodelas could have functioned as necklace beads, on a necklace that used on edge rather than front position. In other words, is a peculiar ornament, but not impossible to do. The Malacates are all artifacts of primary class ceramic artifacts. Decoration on its upper side, many of them are flat on the bottom section, but the shape -all are circular- is variable in their section. In the past, (in Chiapas), it was mentioned that some Malacates were tapered, flat and mixedNavarrete: 1966 existed. Its most definite function, more than any of the remaining ceramic artifacts, always considered as spindle whorls. However, as a secondary or alternate function could also serve as necklace beads. The finding of malacates, plus the Nahuatl site denomination, “Cotton Temple”, implies that Ixcateopan provided large amounts of this plant, already manufactured, to the towns of Tenochtitlan, Texcoco and Tlacopan. It is considered that Ixcateopan spun cotton that was used to make suits of the mexicas soldiers. These data corroborate the narrow relation between Ixcateopan and the center of Mexico; local ceramics remains found here, are similar to those from the Valley of Mexico. These aspects seem to point out that, since Ixcateopan did not have the topographic and strategic characteristics of sites located in the war belt, very possibly it formed part of the Mexica rear and was a storage place, for foods and war equipment. Ixcateopan was a Chontal settlement, and even though neither their language nor physical features are known, archaeological y physical anthropologic studies shall determine the various aspects of this cultural group, unknown to date. However, this prehispanic site had a multi-cultural configuration. In the north of the Guerrero State, Ixcateopan represents the only late postclassical period (1200–1521 AD.) site that has been extensively explored. Excavations from the first field season at this archaeological site, conducted in 2008, provided detection of at least three constructive stages, from 1450 to 1521 AD. This is known from ceramic remains of the denominated type Aztec III, other locally manufactured as an imitation of the previous, fragments of the type called “Rojo Texcoco”, from Cholula and, in addition, two local types colored dark red over beige and “Yestla”-Orange. This unique village could well be named "the marble town", because its narrow streets are paved with this noble material, which magnificently beautifies the physiognomy of the town, due to the borrow sites surrounding the town.{{cite web |first= Arturo|last= Chairez |title= A este singular poblado bien podría agregársele el sobrenombre de "pueblo de mármol" |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/ixcateopan-de-cuauhtemoc-guerrero.html|publisher= Guía México desconocido No. 66 Guerrero |location= |language= Spanish|trans-title=This unique village could well be named "marble town" |date=Jan 2001 |accessdate=Sep 2010}} ===Structures=== Ixcateopan covers an extension of about one hectare and a half, and it is within the city of the same name, where circular altars are distributed and stairways, finished in a dice shape. East and west sections of the site have been explored, which was built on a natural slope. In the first area vestiges of a 56 meters long wall was found, part of a platform; and in the second area (west) a series of terraces were found. The top of this slope was arranged by means of artificial terraces, which facilitated the construction of a large platform on which the ceremonial center was built, as well as plazas, walkways, stairways, living quarters and storage. The constructions, from the postclassical period, were built between 1350 and 1450 CE. The buildings are at least from five different constructive periods; the complex was dedicated to religious ceremonies, administrative and trade activities. Esto a su vez, está íntimamente asociado an actividades de almacenamiento y elaboración de productos derivados del algodón, materia prima que debió ser la principal fuente de abasto y de culto en la región. The archaeological zone consists of a series of overlays built on a natural elevation of the terrain, which occupies approximately 5 thousand square meters. Construction materials employed include: stone slabs, marble, limestone, boulders; and stucco and red paint used for finishing. ===Ceramic=== Ceramic artifacts are a large and important group of samples found, generally mentioned in archaeological reports, serve to describe as well as chronological placement of sites, although seldom are investigation and study specific subjectsDixon: 1959; Sanders: 1961; Green & Lowe: 1967; Nelson: 1973; Howell: 1989; Hermes: 1991 The typical ceramics used at that time was made of three legged hollow “Boxes” (cajetes), and with a streamlined serpent shape, or metlapilcoate. “Cajetes” were painted brown over beige, and there were other decoration painted color brown, black and polychrome beige. ===Gods=== The 16th century geographic relations written by Lucas Pinto, state that in "Ichcateopan", people adored two main Gods, a man and a woman, called "Iztac Tlamacazqui" (white priest) and Acxoyatl Cihuatl (the fir tree woman). Two main priests were in charge of the cult and the sacrifice of virgin women. The population made penances and self-sacrifices; they stuck their tongue and ears with thorns, removed blood and ignited copal. The white priest seemed to represent cotton, part Ixcateopan glyph of the place name. ==Other Sites in the Guerrero State== The zone has older Olmec settlements from the mid preclassical (1200 – 400 BC.) period such as [[Teopantecuanitlán]] and [[Oxtotitlán]], as well as from the classical and postclassical (200 BC. - 1521 AD.), during which period it had a cultural mosaic, and people talked in various languages; tlapanec, mixteco, Nahuatl, Matlatzinca, purépecha, etc. * Cerro de Huashocote.{{cite journal|last= |first= |date= |title=Huitzuco de los Figueroa |trans-title=|journal=Enciclopedia de los Municipios de México |location= |url=http://www.e-local.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/guerrero/municipios/12034a.htm |language=Spanish |accessdate=Sep 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617100147/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/guerrero/municipios/12034a.htm |archivedate=2011-06-17 |df= }} * Tlaxmalac. * Barrio Cantón. * La Maroma. * Teopantecuanitlán, in Copalillo.{{cite journal |last=Castro |first= Marlen |date= |title= En 2007 sólo en Cuetlajuchitlán hubo labores de restauración, dice el INAH |trans-title=In 2007, only Cuetlajuchitlán had restoration work, says INAH |journal= La jornada de guerrero |location= |url= http://www.lajornadaguerrero.com.mx/2007/12/28/index.php?section=cultura&article=011n2cul |language=Spanish |format= |accessdate=Sep 2010}} * La Organera. * Huamuxtitlán. * Los Tepoltzis. * La Sabana. * Palma Sola. * Pezuapan. * [[La Soledad de Maciel (archeological site)|La Soledad de Maciel]]. * [[Oxtotitlán]]. * [[Tehuacalco]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== *[http://posthegemony.blogspot.com/2005/10/codex-mendoza.html A description of the Codex] *[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3686/is_200008/ai_n8917028 Review of ''The Essential Codex Mendoza''] * Campos Ochoa, Moisés, MÉXICO, 1968. Historia del Estado de Guerrero, Época Prehispánica [History of the State of Guerrero, prehispanic period] Vol. I, INAH Gobierno del Estado de Guerrero, Editorial Porrúa, 1998. {{es icon}} *Campbell, Lyle and David Oltrogge, 1980, Proto-Tol (Jicaque), International Journal of American Linguistics, 46:205-223 * Campbell, Lyle. (1979). Middle American languages. In L. Campbell & M. Mithun (Eds.), ''The languages of native America: Historical and comparative assessment'' (pp. 902–1000). Austin: University of Texas Press. *Campbell, Lyle (1997) ''American Indian Languages, The Historical Linguistics of Native America'', Oxford Studies in Anthropological Linguistics, Oxford University Press *Keller, Kathryn C. and Plácido Luciano G., compilers. 1997. ''Diccionario Chontal de Tabasco''. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120310161621/http://www.fondodeculturaeconomica.com/bibDetalle.asp?sec=3674 Ixcatl, el algodon Mexicano (Mexican Cotton)] {{es icon}} *[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=chd Ethnologues page on Highland Chontal] *[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=clo Ethnologues page on Lowland Chontal] *[http://cdi.gob.mx/ini/monografias/chontalesoax.html Information of Chontal culture at INI website]{{es icon}} * [http://www.guerrero.gob.mx/?P=inicio Portal del Gobierno del Estado] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100201211436/http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-guerrero-ixcateopan.php Ixcateopan visiting Mexico {{es icon}}] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120306003153/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_guerrero Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc enciclopedia de los municipios y delegaciones de México (Ixcateopan de Cuauhtémoc encyclopedia of municipalities and delegations of Mexico) {{es icon}}] * [http://members.tripod.com/chilapa_gro.mx/ante_edogro.html Antecedentes históricos del Estado de Guerrero. (Historical background of the State of Guerrero) {{es icon}}] ==Further reading== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100610075932/http://nas.ucdavis.edu/Forbes/new_essays/Guerrero.pdf Guerrero state languages and cultures] {{es icon}} * [[Ixcateopan]] * [[Guerrero]] * [[Chontal Maya language]] * [[Chontal Maya people]] * [[Putún Maya]] * [[Tequistlatecan languages]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ixcateopan (Archaeological Site)}} [[Category:Mesoamerica]] [[Category:Mesoamerican sites]] [[Category:Former populated places in Mexico]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Guerrero]]

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox academic | name = John Blair | honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|FSA|FBA|size=100%}} | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = William John Blair | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1955|3|4}} | birth_place = [[Woking]], [[Surrey]], England | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | region = | period = | occupation = | title = Professor of Medieval History and Archaeology | known_for = | spouse = {{marriage|Kanerva Blair-Heikkinen|2005}} | parents = [[Claude Blair]] | era = | discipline = {{hlist | History | archaeology}} | sub_discipline = [[History of Anglo-Saxon England|Early medieval English history]] | movement = <!-- Should match the ideological movement or denomination (for religious), "school" of thought etc. (e.g. "Anglican", "Postmodernist", "Socialist" or "Green" etc. --> | alma_mater = [[Brasenose College, Oxford]] | thesis_title = Landholding, Church and Settlement in Surrey before 1300 | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1983 | school_tradition = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = <!--Only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = | workplaces = [[The Queen's College, Oxford]] | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influences = <!--Must be referenced from a third party source--> | influenced = <!--Must be referenced from a third party source--> | awards = <!--Notable national level awards only--> | website = | footnotes = }} '''William John Blair''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|sep=,|FSA|FBA}} (born 4 March 1955) is an English historian, [[archaeologist]], and academic, who specialises in [[Anglo-Saxon England]]. He is [[Professor (highest academic rank)|Professor]] of Medieval History and Archaeology at the [[University of Oxford]], and a Fellow of [[The Queen's College, Oxford]]. He gave the 2013 [[Ford Lectures]] at the University of Oxford.
==Early life and education== Blair was born on 4 March 1955 in [[Woking]], Surrey, England.<ref name="Who's Who 2016">{{cite web|title=BLAIR, Prof. (William) John|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whoswho/U247322|website=Who's Who 2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=9 September 2016|date=November 2015}}</ref> His father was [[Claude Blair]], a museum curator and "one of the foremost authorities on historic European metalwork, especially arms and armour",<ref>{{cite news|last1=Badham|first1=Sally|title=Claude Blair obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/mar/12/claude-blair-obituary|accessdate=9 September 2016|work=The Guardian|date=12 March 2010}}</ref> and his mother was Joan Mary Greville Blair (née Drinkwater).<ref name="Who's Who 2016" />
Blair was educated at [[St John's School, Leatherhead]], an [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent school]] in [[Leatherhead]], Surrey.<ref name="Who's Who 2016" /> He then studied at [[Brasenose College, Oxford]], graduating with a [[First Class Honours|first-class]] [[Bachelor of Arts]] (BA) degree in 1976.<ref name="Who's Who 2016" /> He remained at Brasenose College to undertake [[postgraduate research]] and completed his [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (DPhil) degree in 1983.<ref name="Who's Who 2016" /><ref name="bio - Queen's">{{cite web|title=Prof John Blair|url=http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/people/prof-john-blair|website=The Queen's College|publisher=University of Oxford|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref> His [[doctoral thesis]] was titled ''Landholding, Church and Settlement in Surrey before 1300''.<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Blair |first=John |year=1983 |title=Landholding, Church and Settlement in Surrey before 1300 |degree=PhD |location=Oxford |publisher=University of Oxford |oclc=863502663}}</ref>
==Academic career== During his doctoral research, Blair was a [[Junior Research Fellow]] at [[Brasenose College, Oxford]].<ref name="bio - Queen's" /> In 1981, he was elected a [[Fellow (Oxbridge)|Fellow]] of [[The Queen's College, Oxford]].<ref name="Who's Who 2016" /><ref name="bio - Queen's" /> Since then, he has been a [[praelector]] and [[Tutorial system|tutor]] in history at the college.<ref name="Who's Who 2016" /> On 1 October 2006, he was awarded a [[Title of Distinction]] by the [[University of Oxford]] as "professor of Medieval History and Archaeology".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Recognition of Distinction: Titles Awarded, 2005–6|journal=Oxford University Gazette|date=25 October 2006|volume=4784|issue=Supplement 1|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2006-7/supps/1_4784.htm|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
Blair gave the 2013 [[Ford Lectures]] at the University of Oxford.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Blair to give the 2013 Ford Lectures |url=http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/news/john-blair-to-give-the-2013-ford-lectures |work=News |publisher=The Queen's College, Oxford |accessdate=24 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131223114331/http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/news/john-blair-to-give-the-2013-ford-lectures |archivedate=23 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The lecture series was tiled "Building the Anglo-Saxon Landscape".<ref name="bio - faculty">{{cite web|title=Professor John Blair|url=https://www.history.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-john-blair|website=Faculty of History|publisher=University of Oxford|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
On 5 May 1983, Blair was elected [[Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London]] (FSA).<ref>{{cite web |title=Fellows Directory – B |url= http://www.sal.org.uk/about-us/fellows-directory/?l=B |work=About us |publisher=Society of Antiquaries |accessdate=24 May 2014}}</ref> He was elected [[Fellow of the British Academy]] (FBA) in 2008.<ref name=BritishAcademy>{{cite web |title=Professor John Blair |url= http://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-john-blair |work=British Academy Fellows |publisher=British Academy |accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 2005, Blair married Kanerva Heikkinen. Together they have two children; one daughter and one son.<ref name="Who's Who 2016" />
==Selected works== *{{cite book |last=Blair |first=John |date=1991 |title=Early Medieval Surrey: Landholding, Church and Settlement before 1300 |place=Gloucester |publisher=Alan Sutton Publishing |isbn=978-0-86299-780-9}} *{{cite book |last=Blair |first=John |authorlink=John Blair (historian) |year=1994 |title=Anglo-Saxon Oxfordshire |place=Oxford, Stroud and Dover, NH |publisher=Oxfordshire Books and Alan Sutton Publishing |isbn=978-0-7509-0147-5}} *{{cite book |last=Blair |first=John |date=2000 |title=The Anglo-Saxon Age: a very short introduction |place=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-285403-2}} *{{cite book |last=Blair |first=John |date=2005 |title=The Church in Anglo-Saxon Society |place=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-822695-6}} *{{cite book |editor-last=Blair |editor-first=John |date=2007 |title=Waterways and Canal-building in Medieval England |place=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-921715-1}} *{{cite book |last=Blair |first=John |date=2013 |title=The British Culture of Anglo-Saxon Settlement |place=Cambridge |publisher=Department of Anglo-Saxon, Norse & Celtic |isbn=978-0-9571862-9-3}} *{{cite book |editor1-last=Lapidge |editor1-first=Michael |editor1-link=Michael Lapidge |editor2-last=Blair |editor2-first=John |editor3-last=Keynes |editor3-first=Simon |editor3-link=Simon Keynes |editor4-last=Scragg |editor4-first=Donald |date=2014 |title=The Wiley-Blackwell Encyclopedia of Anglo-Saxon England |place=Chichester |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |isbn=978-0-470-65632-7 |edition=2nd}}

Mem. Lang. | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = | frequency = 8 issues a year | history = 1985–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 4.014 | impact-year = 2010 | website = http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-memory-and-language | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 11148687 | LCCN = 85644519 | CODEN = | ISSN = 0749-596X | eISSN = 1096-0821 }} The '''''Journal of Memory and Language''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] [[academic journal]] of [[cognitive science]], which focuses primarily on the issues of [[memory]] and [[sentence processing|language comprehension]]. It has been published by [[Elsevier]] since 1985. The current [[editor-in-chief]] is Richard Gerrig ([[Stony Brook University]]).
The [[Institute for Scientific Information]]'s ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'' ranked the journal first in the field of linguistics, with a 2010 [[impact factor]] of 4.014.
== Abstracting and indexing == The journal is indexed in Abstracts in Anthropology, [[Current Contents]], Current Index to Journals in Education, [[Science Citation Index|Neuroscience Citation Index]], [[PsycINFO]], Research Alert, [[Scopus]], and the [[Social Sciences Citation Index]].

{{Infobox scientist |name = Kristen R. Ghodsee |image= Kristen Ghodsee Podium 2.jpg |caption = Kristen Ghodsee in 2011 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|04|26}} |birth_place = |residence = |nationality = [[United States of America|American]] |field = [[Ethnography]]
[[Gender theory]]
[[Feminism]]
[[Women's Studies]]
[[Anthropology]] |work_institution =[[University of Pennsylvania]] |alma_mater = [[University of California at Berkeley]]
[[University of California at Santa Cruz]] |awards = [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] |title = }} {{Anthropology}} '''Kristen R. Ghodsee''' (born April 26, 1970) is an American ethnographer and Professor of Russian and East European Studies at the [[University of Pennsylvania]]Faculty page: https://rees.sas.upenn.edu/people/kristen-r-ghodsee known primarily for her ethnographic work on post-communist [[Bulgaria]] as well as being a contributor to the field of postsocialist [[gender studies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/exploratory-seminars/gender-socialism-and-postsocialism|title=Gender, Socialism, and Postsocialism: Transatlantic Dialogues | Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University|publisher=Radcliffe.harvard.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Contrary to the prevailing opinion of most feminist scholars in the 1990s who believed that women would be disproportionately harmed by the collapse of [[communism]], Ghodsee argued that many East European women would actually fare better than men in newly competitive labor markets because of the [[cultural capital]] that they had acquired before 1989.{{cite web|url=http://wings.buffalo.edu/ARD/cgi/showme.cgi?keycode=2812|title=Anthropology Review Database|publisher=Wings.buffalo.edu|date=2008-02-25|accessdate=2015-04-02}} She was critical of the role of Western feminist [[nongovernmental organizations]] doing work among East European women in the 1990s. She examined the shifting gender relations of Muslim minorities after communism,{{cite web|author=Kristen Ghodsee|url=http://intl-eep.sagepub.com/content/early/2010/04/21/0888325410364254|title=Minarets after Marx: Islam, Communist Nostalgia, and the Common Good in Postsocialist Bulgaria|publisher=Intl-eep.sagepub.com|date=2010-04-21|accessdate=2015-04-02}} and the intersections of Islamic beliefs and practices with the ideological remains of [[Marxism–Leninism]].{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1556-3502.2009.50531_2.x/abstract|title=The Headscarf Debate in Bulgaria |date=2009-05-07|accessdate=2015-04-02|doi=10.1111/j.1556-3502.2009.50531_2.x|volume=50|issue=5|journal=Anthropology News|pages=31–32}} ==Career== Ghodsee received her B.A. from the [[University of California at Santa Cruz]] and her Ph.D. from the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. She has been awarded numerous research fellowships, including those from the [[National Science Foundation]], [[Fulbright]], the [[American Council of Learned Societies]],{{cite web|url=http://www.acls.org/research/fellow.aspx?cid=8c706223-f8a4-db11-8d10-000c2903e717|title=Kristen R. Ghodsee G'09, F'05|publisher=Acls.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}} the [[International Research & Exchanges Board]] (IREX), and the National Council for Eurasian and East European Research. She was a resident fellow at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in Princeton,{{cite web|url=http://www.sss.ias.edu/people/past-scholars|title=Past Scholars | School of Social Science|publisher=Sss.ias.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ias.edu/people/cos/users/kghodsee|title=Ghodsee, Kristen Rogheh | Institute for Advanced Study|publisher=Ias.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}} [[The Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]] in Washington,{{cite web|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/staff/kristen-r-ghodsee|title=Kristen R. Ghodsee|publisher=Wilsoncenter.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}} The [[Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research]] in [[Rostock, Germany]], the [[Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study]] at [[Harvard University]],{{cite web|url=http://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/people/kristen-ghodsee|title=Fellow | Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University|publisher=Radcliffe.harvard.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}} and the [[Freiburg Institute for Advanced Studies]] (FRIAS).{{cite web|url=https://www.frias.uni-freiburg.de/en/people/present-fellows/ghodsee|title=Prof. Dr. Kristen R. Ghodsee — Freiburg Institute for Advanced Studies|publisher=Frias.uni-freiburg.de|date=2011-08-10|accessdate=2015-04-02}} In 2012, she was elected president of the Society for Humanistic Anthropology.{{cite web|url=http://www.aaanet.org/sections/sha/officers-and-board-members|title=Officers and Board Members | Society for Humanistic Anthropology|publisher=Aaanet.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}} ==Red Nostalgia and Neoliberalism== In 2004, Ghodsee published one of the first articles considering the gendered aspects of the growing [[nostalgia]] for the communist era in Eastern Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.univie.ac.at/Geschichte/LHOMME/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=19%3A15-1-2004-postkommunismen&catid=5%3Alhomme-zfg&Itemid=6&lang=en |title=15, 1 (2004), Post/Kommunismen |publisher=Univie.ac.at |date= |accessdate=2015-04-02}} Already beginning in the late 1990s, various scholars were examining the phenomenon of ''[[Ostalgie]]'' in former East Germany and what had been called “[[Yugo-nostalgia]]” in the successor states of the former Yugoslavia.{{cite web|url=http://diasporiclivesofobjects2012.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/east-german-objects-nostaligia.pdf|format=PDF|title='(N)Ostalgie' for the present: Memory, longing, and East German things|author=Daphne Berdahla|publisher=Diasporiclivesofobjects2012.files.wordpress.com|accessdate=2015-04-02}} This earlier work on the emergence of communist nostalgia focused on its consumer aspects and considered the phenomenon a necessary phase that post-socialist populations needed to pass through in order to fully break with their communist pasts.{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1525/ahu.2000.25.2.131/abstract|title="Go, Trabi, Go!": Reflections on a Car and Its Symbolization over Time |accessdate=2015-04-02 | doi=10.1525/ahu.2000.25.2.131|volume=25|issue=2|journal=Anthropology and Humanism|pages=131–141}} In contrast, her concept of "red nostalgia" considered how individual men and women experienced the loss of the real material benefits of the socialist past.{{cite web|url=http://wamc.org/post/dr-kristen-ghodsee-bowdoin-college-nostalgia-communism|title=Dr. Kristen Ghodsee, Bowdoin College - Nostalgia for Communism|publisher=Wamc.org|date=2011-11-01|accessdate=2015-04-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurozine.com/articles/2004-11-09-lhommeabstr-en.html|title=Abstracts for L'Homme 1/2004|publisher=Eurozine.com|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Rather than just a wistful glance back at a lost youth, red nostalgia formed the basis of an emerging critique of the political and economic upheavals that characterized the post-socialist era.{{cite web|url=http://www.dissentmagazine.org/article/the-specter-still-haunts-revisiting-1989|title=The Specter Still Haunts: Revisiting 1989|publisher=Dissentmagazine.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2011/12/05/confidence-in-democracy-and-capitalism-wanes-in-former-soviet-union|title=Confidence in Democracy and Capitalism Wanes in Former Soviet Union - Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|publisher=Pewglobal.org|date=2011-12-05|accessdate=2015-04-02}} More recently, Ghodsee has explored the politics of [[public memory]] about communism, World War II, and the Bulgarian Holocaust.{{cite web|url=http://muftah.org/historical-amnesia-in-eastern-europe|title=Victims of Communism and Historical Amnesia in Eastern Europe|publisher=Muftah.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}}[https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5406/historypresent.4.2.0115 Ghodsee profile], jstor.org; accessed April 11, 2015. In her 2017 book ''Red Hangover: Legacies of Twentieth-Century Communism'', Ghodsee posits that the triumphalist attitudes of Western powers at the end of the [[Cold War]], and the fixation with linking all leftist and [[socialist]] political ideals with the horrors of [[Stalinism]], allowed [[neoliberalism]] to fill the void, which undermined democratic institutions and reforms, leaving a trail of economic misery, unemployment, hopelessness and rising inequality throughout the former [[Eastern Bloc]] and much of the West in the following decades that has fueled the rise of extremist [[nationalism]] in both the former and the latter. She says that the time has come "to rethink the democratic project and finally do the work necessary to either rescue it from the death grip of neoliberalism, or replace it with a new political ideal that leads us forward to a new stage of human history."{{cite book |last=Ghodsee|first=Kristen|date=2017 |title=Red Hangover: Legacies of Twentieth-Century Communism|url=https://www.dukeupress.edu/red-hangover|location= |publisher=[[Duke University Press]]|pages=xix-xx, 134, 197–200 |isbn=978-0822369493|author-link=Kristen R. Ghodsee}} ==Literary ethnography== Ghodsee's later work combines traditional ethnography with a literary sensibility, employing the stylistic conventions of creative nonfiction to produce academic texts that are meant to be accessible to a wider audience.''From Notes to Narrative: Writing Ethnographies that Everyone Can Read''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2016 Inspired by the work of [[Clifford Geertz]] and the conventions of “[[thick description]]”, she is a proponent of “literary ethnography.”{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1548-1409.2011.01091.x/abstract|title=Walking the Walk: On the Epistemological Merits of Literary Ethnography |date=2011-12-09|accessdate=2015-04-02|doi=10.1111/j.1548-1409.2011.01091.x|volume=36|issue=2|journal=Anthropology and Humanism|pages=178–192}} This genre uses narrative tension, dialogue and lyrical prose in the presentation of ethnographic data. Furthermore, Ghodsee argues that literary ethnographies are often “documentary ethnographies,” i.e. ethnographies whose primary purpose is to explore the inner working of a particular culture without necessarily subsuming these observations to a specific theoretical agenda.{{cite web|url=http://literary-ethnography.tumblr.com/post/13995875783/syrian-episodes-fathers-sons-and-an|title=Literary Ethnography|publisher=Literary-ethnography.tumblr.com|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Ghodsee's third book, ''Lost in Transition: Ethnographies of Everyday Life After Communism'', combines personal ethnographic essays with ethnographic fiction to paint a human portrait of the political and economic transition from communism.{{cite web|url=http://www.bowdoin.edu/books/lost-in-transition/images/lost-in-transition-intro.pdf|format=PDF|title=The Road to Bulgaria, 1983-1990|publisher=Bowdoin.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}} While some reviewers have found the book “compelling and highly readable,”{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/418793.article|title=Lost in Transition: Ethnographies of Everyday Life after Communism | General|publisher=Timeshighereducation.co.uk|date=2012-01-26|accessdate=2015-04-02}} and “an enchanting, deeply intimate and experimental ethnographic narrative,”{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/anthropological_quarterly/v085/85.2.jung.pdf|title=Project MUSE - Lost In Transition: Ethnographies of the Everyday Life After Communism (review)|doi=10.1353/anq.2012.0032|publisher=Muse.jhu.edu|accessdate=2015-04-02}} others have faulted the book for telling a story “at the expense of theory.”{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1469-8676.12004_9/abstract|title=Lost in transition. Ethnographies of everyday life after communism by Ghodsee, Kristen |date=2013-02-06|accessdate=2015-04-02|doi=10.1111/1469-8676.12004_9|volume=21|issue=1|journal=Social Anthropology|pages=104–106}} That the book was judged "remarkably free of academic jargon and neologisms”{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.americanethnologist.org/2013/lost-in-transition-ethnographies-of-everyday-life-after-communism-kristen-ghodsee|title=Lost in Transition: Ethnographies of Everyday Life after Communism. Kristen Ghodsee|publisher=Americanethnologist.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}} produced very “mixed feelings” within the scholarly community with one critic stating that “the somewhat unconventional technique of incorporating fiction alongside her [Ghodsee's] ethnographic vignettes feels a bit forced.”{{cite web|url=http://coa.sagepub.com/content/32/4/501.extract |title=Kristen Ghodsee, Lost in Transition: Ethnographies of Everyday Life after Communism|publisher=Coa.sagepub.com|date=2012-12-01|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Outside of academia, however, one reviewer claimed that ''Lost in Transition'' "is very easy to read and is, in fact, impossible to put down, largely because it is so well-written."[http://www.vagabond.bg/politics/2564-lost-in-transition.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016004504/http://www.vagabond.bg/politics/2564-lost-in-transition.html |date=October 16, 2013 }} ==Awards== Kristen Ghodsee's 2010 book, ''Muslim Lives in Eastern Europe: Gender, Ethnicity and the Transformation of Islam in Postsocialist Bulgaria'' was awarded the 2010 Barbara [[Heldt Prize]] for the best book{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bowdoin.edu/news/archives/1academicnews/007867.shtml |title=Ghodsee Book Wins Award For Best in Field, Academic Spotlight (Bowdoin) |publisher=Bowdoin.edu |date=2010-10-14 |accessdate=2015-04-02}} by a woman in Slavic/Eurasian/East European Studies,{{cite web|url=http://www.awsshome.org/past-awards.html#heldt |title=Association for Women in Slavic Studies (AWSS) |publisher=Awsshome.org |date= |accessdate=2015-04-02}} the 2011 Harvard University/Davis Center Book Prize{{cite web|author=Nina Bahadur |url=http://press.princeton.edu/blog/2011/10/24/kristen-ghodsee-wins-the-2011-davis-center-book-prize/ |title=Kristen Ghodsee wins the 2011 Davis Center Book Prize |publisher=Press.princeton.edu |date=2011-10-24 |accessdate=2015-04-02}} from the Association for Slavic, East European and Eurasian Studies, the 2011 John D. Bell Book Prize{{cite web|author=Nina Bahadur |url=http://press.princeton.edu/blog/2011/11/18/muslim-lives-in-eastern-europe-wins-the-john-d-bell-memorial-book-prize/ |title="Muslim Lives in Eastern Europe" wins the John D. Bell Memorial Book Prize |publisher=Press.princeton.edu |date=2011-11-18 |accessdate=2015-04-02}} from the Bulgarian Studies Association and the 2011 William A. Douglass Prize in Europeanist Anthropology{{cite web|author=Jessica Pellien|url=http://press.princeton.edu/blog/2011/09/01/muslim-lives-in-eastern-europe-wins-2011-william-a-douglass-prize-in-europeanist-anthropology|title=Muslim Lives in Eastern Europe wins 2011 William A. Douglass Prize in Europeanist Anthropology|publisher=Press.princeton.edu|date=2011-09-01|accessdate=2015-04-02}} from the Society for the Anthropology of Europe{{cite web|url=http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=H-SAE&month=1109&week=a&msg=9L2sz8kNTHeyYQWMvLUBaQ&user=&pw=|title=H-Net Discussion Networks - SAE: 2011 Douglass Prize to Kristen Ghodsee |publisher=H-net.msu.edu|date=2011-09-06|accessdate=2015-04-02}} of the [[American Anthropological Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wiareport.com/2011/09/bowdoin-professor-wins-book-award|title=Bowdoin Professor Wins Book Award: Women In Academia Report|publisher=Wiareport.com|date=2011-09-15|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Ghodsee also won the 2011 Ethnographic Fiction Prize {{cite web|url=http://www.aaanet.org/sections/sha/sha-prize-winners/ |title=SHA Prize Winners | Society for Humanistic Anthropology |publisher=Aaanet.org |date= |accessdate=2015-04-02}} from the Society for Humanistic Anthropology for the short story "Tito Trivia," included in her book, ''Lost in Transition: Ethnographies of Everyday Life After Communism''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dukeupress.edu/Booksellers/awards.php |title=Duke University Press |publisher=Dukeupress.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-04-02}} Together with co-author, Charles Dorn, Ghodsee was awarded the 2012 Best Article Prize from the History of Education Society (HES) for Dorn and Ghodsee's article in the journal ''[[Diplomatic History (journal)|Diplomatic History]]'': “The Cold War Politicization of Literacy: UNESCO, Communism, and the World Bank.”{{cite web|url=http://www.h-net.org/~diplo/reviews/PDF/AR372.pdf |title=H-Diplo|publisher=H-Net.org|date=2015-03-27|accessdate=2015-04-02}} In 2012, she won a John Simon [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] for her work in anthropology and cultural studies.{{cite web|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/17215-kristen-r-ghodsee|title=Kristen R. Ghodsee - John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|publisher=Gf.org|accessdate=2015-04-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/news/2-Maine-educators-win-Guggenheim-fellowships.html|title=2 Maine educators win Guggenheim fellowships - The Portland Press Herald/Maine Sunday Telegram|publisher=Pressherald.com|date=2012-04-15|accessdate=2015-04-02}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.pressherald.com/life/Mainers-win-Guggenheims.html|title=Bowdoin, Colby profs win Guggenheims - The Portland Press Herald/Maine Sunday Telegram|publisher=Pressherald.com|date=2012-04-13|accessdate=2015-04-02}} ==Criticism== Ghodsee's scholarly work on gender and everyday life during and after socialism has drawn criticism from both Western [[feminists]] and [[communists]]. In a 2014 essay in the ''European Journal of Women’s Studies'', philosopher Nanette Funk included Ghodsee among a handful of “Revisionist Feminist Scholars” who uncritically tout the achievements of communist era women's organizations, ignoring the oppressive nature of authoritarian regimes in [[Eastern Europe]].{{cite journal | last1 = Funk | first1 = Nanette | year = 2014 | title = A very tangled knot: Official state socialist women's organizations, women's agency and feminism in Eastern European state socialism | url = http://ejw.sagepub.com/content/21/4/344.abstract | journal = European Journal of Women’s Studies | volume = 21 | issue = 4| pages = 344–360 | doi=10.1177/1350506814539929}} Funk argued that the “Feminist Revisionists” are too eager in their “desire to find women’s agency in an anti-capitalist Marxist past,” and that this “leads to distortions” and “making overly bold claims” about the possibilities for feminist activism under communism.{{cite journal | last1 = Funk | first1 = Nanette | year = 2015 | title = (K)not so: A response to Kristen Ghodsee | url = http://ejw.sagepub.com/content/22/3/350.refs | journal = European Journal of Women's Studies | volume = 22 | issue = 3| pages = 350–355 | doi=10.1177/1350506815592759}} In response, Ghodsee asserts that her scholarship seeks to expand the idea of feminism beyond the attainment of "personal self-actualization", asserting that "if the goal of feminism is to improve women’s lives, along with eliminating discrimination and promoting equality with men, then there is ample room to reconsider what Krassimira Daskalova calls the ‘women-friendly’ policies of state socialist women's organizations." She notes that "the goal of much recent scholarship on state socialist women’s organizations is to show how the communist ideology could lead to real improvements in women’s literacy, education, professional training, as well as access to health care, the extension of paid maternity leave, and a reduction of their economic dependence on men (facts that even Funk does not deny)."{{cite journal |last1= Ghodsee|first1=Kristen R.|year= 2015|title=Untangling the knot: A response to Nanette Funk|url=http://scholar.harvard.edu/files/kristenghodsee/files/ghodsee_response_to_funk_-_ejws.pdf|journal=European Journal of Women’s Studies|volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=248–252 |doi=10.1177/1350506815571264}} ==Books== *Kristen R.
